metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of differential global position system (DGPS) measurements at the super site around the Dayekou Guantan forest station (2008)
metadata.description:
The super sample plot is composed of 16 sub samples. In order to locate each tree in the sample plot and facilitate the location of the base station point for ground-based radar observation, it is necessary to measure the geodetic coordinates of the sub sample plot corner point and the preset base station point for ground-based radar. The location of these points and each tree is measured by total station. Because the total station measures relative coordinates, in order to obtain geodetic coordinates, it is necessary to use differential GPS (DGPS) to measure at least one reference point around the super sample plot with high precision. In addition, we also use DGPS to observe the geodetic coordinates of all corner points of the subsample, and the measurement results can form the verification of the total station measurement results. The data set is based on all the positioning results measured by DGPS, excluding the positioning results of total station. 
The measurement time is from June 1 to 13, 2008, using the French Thales differential GPS measurement system, model z-max. The observation method is to use two GPS receivers for synchronous static measurement, one is the base station, which is set next to Gansu Water Conservation Forest Research Institute (the WGS geodetic coordinate of the base station is a first-class benchmark introduced from Zhangye City through multi station observation using z-max). The other is the mobile station, which is placed on the observation point of super sample plot. The observation time of each point varies from 10, 15, 20, 25, 30 minutes. The specific time depends on the satellite signal. The signal difference time is measured for several minutes more. Finally, the final positioning result is obtained by using the processing software of the instrument. WGS geodetic coordinate system is used for the positioning results. 
Firstly, six temporary control points were measured in the open area next to the super sample plot, providing reference points for the total station to measure the position of trees in the super sample plot. Then, flow stations were set up on each corner of 16 sub plots of super plot, and the coordinates of corner points were measured, and 41 observation points were obtained. The dataset stores the positioning results of these 47 points. 
This data is only for project use and not for external sharing.

background: Airborne laser scanning data have been widely used to retrieve the forest structure parameters. Generation of digital terrain model (DTM) in forested area is very important for estimation of canopy height and fractional cover describing vegetation cover density which serves as an important parameter for biosphere modeling. In forested area, DTM can be generated from ground points of lidar data and fractional cover can be derived from vegetation points of lidar data. Separation of ground points and above-ground points is a significant work for retrieval of forest structure information during the processing of LIDAR data. In previous studies, different algorithms had been developed for generation of DTM from airborne laser scanning data.
research objective: We proposed a method to separate ground points and vegetation points from discrete return, small footprint airborne laser scanner data, called skewness change algorithm. So this study presents a method for synchronous estimation of DTM and fractional vegetation cover in forested area from airborne LIDAR height and intensity data.
challenges: As for the laser scan system recording discrete returns, it is difficult to separate the two kinds of points from total lidar data by the order of discrete returns or height above ground, especially in sloped area.
methods: A few vegetation points which were classified into the ground points were removed as noise before the generation of DTM. This method was tested in a test area of 10000 square meters. A LiteMapper-5600 laser system was used and a flight was carried out over a ground of 700 ―800 m. In this tested area, a total number of 1546 field measurement ground points were measured with a total station TOPCON GTS-602 and TOPCON GTS-7002 for validation of DTM and the mean error value is −18.5 cm and the RMSE (root mean square error) is ±20.9 cm. A data trap sizes of 4 m in diameter from airborne laser scanner data was selected to compute vegetation fraction cover. Validation of fractional vegetation cover was carried out using 15 hemispherical photographs, which are georeferenced to centimeter accuracy by differential GPS. The gap fraction was computed over a range of zenith angles 10° using the gap light analyzer (GLA) from each hemispherical photograph.
dataset: In this tested area, a total number of 1546 field measurement ground points were measured with a total station TOPCON GTS-602 and TOPCON GTS-7002 for validation of DTM. Validation of fractional vegetation cover was carried out using 15 hemispherical photographs, which are georeferenced to centimeter accuracy by differential GPS.
findings: The R2 for the regression of fractional vegetation cover from these ALS data and the respective field measurements is 0.7554.

background: Forests play an important role in the global carbon cycle, and forest biomass carbon sequestration measures have become a significant component of global emission reduction efforts. Forest biomass is the energy basis and nutrient source for the functioning of the entire forest ecosystem, and it is fundamental for studying forest productivity, net primary productivity, carbon cycling, and global change research. Currently, the estimation of regional forest biomass mainly relies on stratified sampling techniques that involve establishing a large number of ground measurement plots, followed by statistical methods for estimation. Methods based on radar and LiDAR have become a research hotspot both domestically and internationally. Traditional single-angle optical remote sensing data primarily provide spectral information and horizontal structural information of vegetation, lacking vertical structural information. As biomass increases, remote sensing signals are prone to saturation. Radar data with longer wavelengths can provide vertical structural information of vegetation; however, airborne and spaceborne polarized interferometric synthetic aperture radar data are still quite difficult to obtain. The rapid development and commercialization of airborne systems currently offer a promising technological means for estimating forest parameters.
research objective: This article aims to estimate the individual tree biomass of coniferous forests using high-sampling-density point cloud data. The main research content includes two aspects: first, how to accurately estimate the structural parameters of individual trees; second, how to establish relevant growth equations for individual tree biomass.
challenges: Due to the positioning errors of individual trees, only a portion of the individual trees were matched and used for estimation. It is important to note that the biomass estimation equations related to individual trees cannot be directly applied to estimate forest biomass at a regional scale. This is because the matched trees only account for a part of the total number of trees in the sample plot. Further research is needed to explore how to extend the application to regional-scale biomass estimation.
methods: A canopy height model is generated from point cloud data, and then individual tree structural parameters are estimated from it. The algorithms proposed in the literature have been optimized, including optimizations for the processing algorithm and the individual tree crown feature recognition algorithm. When generating the canopy height model, the number, values, and positions of the crown vertices will change after low-pass filtering and smoothing processing. A new raster data smoothing algorithm is proposed for generating the canopy height model. Based on the linear and logarithmic optimal regression equations for individual tree structural parameters, the estimated biomass growth equation for individual trees is obtained by solving the coupled equations with the measured relevant growth equations.
dataset: The field survey was conducted from July 5 to July 9, 2012. The size of the super plot was set at 100m x 100m, in a square shape. Within the boundary of the super plot, 127 individuals were identified from point cloud data, and 102 individuals were automatically matched.
findings: Through the measured diameter at breast height and the estimated tree height and crown width, the linear and logarithmic regression equations yield a good consistency in biomass, and both can be used to estimate the biomass of individual trees.

Verification.Question: Is it possible to separate ground points from vegetation points using airborne laser scanning data for forest structure analysis?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to obtain accurate geospatial coordinates for forest structures?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to obtain accurate geospatial coordinates for forest structures is the use of differential GPS (DGPS) for high-precision measurements. In the described field, DGPS was used to measure geospatial coordinates for predefined reference points and corner points of subplots within a forested area.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when processing airborne LIDAR data for forest structure information?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge faced when processing airborne LIDAR data for forest structure information is the difficulty in separating ground points from vegetation points, especially in sloped areas. Different algorithms have been developed to address this challenge, such as the skewness change algorithm for estimating digital terrain models (DTM) and fractional vegetation cover.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of how point cloud data is used in estimating individual tree biomass in forest studies?
Example.Answer: An example of using point cloud data for estimating individual tree biomass involves generating a canopy height model from the data to estimate the structural parameters of trees. This method includes optimizing algorithms for tree crown feature recognition and developing regression equations to estimate individual tree biomass, which can be further validated with field measurements.

Definition.Question: What is differential GPS (DGPS) and how is it used in precise data collection for forest studies?
Definition.Answer: Differential GPS (DGPS) is a method of enhancing the accuracy of GPS positioning by using a network of fixed ground-based reference stations. In forest studies, DGPS is used for high-precision localization of reference points, such as in the 黑河综合遥感联合试验, where it ensures accurate geodetic coordinates for measuring subplots and individual trees.

Definition.Question: What challenges arise when separating ground and vegetation points in airborne laser scanning data, and how can these be addressed?
Definition.Answer: Separating ground and vegetation points in airborne laser scanning data, particularly in sloped areas, is challenging due to the difficulty in distinguishing points based on discrete returns or height above ground. This can be addressed by using algorithms like the skewness change algorithm, which aids in the synchronous estimation of digital terrain models and fractional vegetation cover.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of differential GPS (DGPS) for measuring geodetic coordinates in forested areas compare to the use of airborne laser scanning data for generating digital terrain models?
Comparison.Answer: Differential GPS (DGPS) is used to achieve high precision in measuring geodetic coordinates by using a base station and a rover station, which allows for precise location of points such as tree positions in a forest. In contrast, airborne laser scanning data is used to generate digital terrain models and estimate canopy height by separating ground points from vegetation points. DGPS focuses on accurate positioning of specific points, while airborne LIDAR provides a more comprehensive model of the terrain and vegetation structure.

Interpretation.Question: How can differential GPS (DGPS) techniques enhance the accuracy of geospatial data collection in forested areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Differential GPS techniques can enhance the accuracy of geospatial data collection by providing high-precision geodetic coordinates for reference points, which are crucial for validating measurements from other instruments like total stations. In forested areas, this allows for accurate positioning of individual trees and predefined radar base station points, even in challenging terrain.

Interpretation.Question: What are the challenges associated with using lidar data for generating digital terrain models in forested areas, and how can these challenges be overcome?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges with using lidar data in forested areas include separating ground points from above-ground points, especially on sloped terrain. This can be addressed by developing algorithms, such as the skewness change algorithm, to distinguish between ground and vegetation points, improving the accuracy of digital terrain models and fractional vegetation cover estimations.

Interpretation.Question: In terms of improving forest biomass estimation, how can point cloud data be utilized to develop growth equations for individual trees?
Interpretation.Answer: Point cloud data can be utilized to generate canopy height models and estimate structural parameters of individual trees. By optimizing algorithms for tree structure recognition and smoothing data, linear and logarithmic regression equations can be established to estimate the biomass of individual trees, based on parameters like diameter at breast height, tree height, and crown width.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for differential GPS (DGPS) measurement to validate total station measurements in forested areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: In forested areas, the need for differential GPS (DGPS) measurement arises to obtain high-precision geodetic coordinates for reference points. This is necessary because total station measurements provide relative coordinates, which need to be validated and corrected to absolute geodetic coordinates for accurate positioning of each tree and observation point, especially for radar observation baseline points.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to accurately separate ground and vegetation points in forested areas using LIDAR data?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Accurately separating ground and vegetation points in forested areas using LIDAR data is challenging because discrete return laser scanning systems make it difficult to distinguish between the two types of points based on the order of returns or height above ground, particularly in sloped areas. This separation is crucial for retrieving accurate forest structure information, such as generating digital terrain models (DTMs) and estimating fractional vegetation cover.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty of estimating regional forest biomass from single-tree biomass equations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Estimating regional forest biomass from single-tree biomass equations is difficult due to the limited matching of individual trees, which only represents a portion of the total number of trees in a sample plot. This limitation means that the growth equations derived for single-tree biomass estimation cannot be directly applied to regional scales without further research and adaptation to account for all trees within the area.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might arise from using differential GPS (DGPS) for measuring geodetic coordinates in forested areas compared to traditional methods?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using DGPS for measuring geodetic coordinates in forested areas allows for high-precision measurements which can provide reference points for validating data from other instruments like a total station. This can enhance the accuracy of forest structure measurements and serve as a basis for validating other datasets, especially in complex terrains where traditional methods might provide less accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the development of algorithms for separating ground and vegetation points from LIDAR data impact the generation of digital terrain models (DTMs) in forested regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The development of such algorithms can significantly improve the accuracy and reliability of DTMs by more effectively distinguishing between ground and vegetation points. This can lead to better estimates of forest canopy height and fractional cover, which are crucial for biosphere modeling and forest management. Accurate DTMs aid in understanding forest structure and dynamics, which can influence ecological assessments and resource management.

Causal Consequence.Question: What potential consequences could arise from using high-density point cloud data for estimating individual tree biomass in temperate coniferous forests?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using high-density point cloud data can allow for precise estimation of individual tree biomass by generating detailed canopy height models and structural parameters. This precision can lead to the development of accurate growth equations for biomass estimation, which are essential for carbon cycle studies and forest productivity assessments. However, challenges in matching individual trees and extending these models to larger scales could limit application scope without further research and methodological advancements.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to measure the geodetic coordinates of subplots and radar base station points using differential GPS in forested areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Measuring the geodetic coordinates of subplots and radar base station points using differential GPS is crucial for accurately positioning each tree within the super plot and facilitating the location of ground-based radar observation stations. This precision is necessary to verify the results obtained from the total station measurements and ensure high accuracy in forest structure studies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of developing a method to separate ground points and vegetation points from airborne laser scanning data in forested areas?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of developing a method to separate ground points and vegetation points from airborne laser scanning data is to enable the generation of digital terrain models (DTM) and estimation of fractional vegetation cover. These parameters are essential for understanding forest structure and modeling biosphere interactions, especially given the challenges of separating these points in sloped areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can differential GPS (DGPS) be used to enhance the accuracy of georeferencing points in a forested area for data collection purposes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Differential GPS (DGPS) can be used by setting up a base station and a rover station, where the base station is placed at a known reference point and the rover station is placed at the observation points within the forested area. The positions are measured using synchronous static observations, and the data is processed using post-differential correction to improve accuracy. This method helps in obtaining precise geographical coordinates necessary for accurate georeferencing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to separate ground points from vegetation points in LIDAR data to create a canopy height model?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: One method involves using the skewness change algorithm to differentiate ground points from vegetation points in discrete return, small footprint airborne laser scanner data. The process includes removing vegetation points misclassified as ground points before generating the DTM. This method allows simultaneous estimation of DTM and fractional vegetation cover by utilizing both height and intensity data from the LIDAR.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the precise measurement of forest canopy structure in remote areas?
Enablement.Answer: The use of airborne laser scanning data and differential GPS positioning are key techniques. Airborne laser scanning data, such as those from a LiteMapper-5600 laser system, can generate digital terrain models and fractional vegetation cover, while differential GPS provides high precision for georeferencing field measurements.

Enablement.Question: What methods enable researchers to separate ground points from vegetation points in LIDAR data collected in sloped forested areas?
Enablement.Answer: The development of algorithms like the skewness change algorithm helps in separating these points from discrete return, small footprint airborne laser scanner data. This approach allows for synchronous estimation of digital terrain models and fractional vegetation cover by removing vegetation points classified as noise.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of differential GPS in forested areas be expected to provide higher accuracy in data collection compared to using only relative coordinates from a total station?
Expectation.Answer: Differential GPS provides high-precision geodetic coordinates, which can be used to verify and correct relative coordinates obtained from a total station, ensuring higher accuracy in positioning each tree and observation point within forested areas.

Expectation.Question: Why is it anticipated that differentiating between ground points and vegetation points in LIDAR data presents challenges, especially in sloped areas?
Expectation.Answer: Differentiating these points is challenging due to the difficulty in separating discrete returns of LIDAR data by their order or height above ground, which is exacerbated in sloped areas where topographical variations complicate the separation process.

Judgmental.Question: How might the use of differential GPS (DGPS) improve the accuracy of forest structure data collection, and what are the potential limitations of this method?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of differential GPS (DGPS) can significantly enhance the accuracy of forest structure data collection by providing precise geolocation for ground reference points. This method is particularly beneficial for calibrating other instruments, such as total stations used for detailed measurements. However, potential limitations include the dependency on satellite signal quality, which can vary, and the necessity for a static base station, which may not always be feasible in remote areas.

Judgmental.Question: In your judgment, what are the potential benefits and drawbacks of using high-density point cloud data for estimating individual tree biomass in temperate coniferous forests?
Judgmental.Answer: High-density point cloud data can provide detailed structural parameters for individual trees, leading to more accurate biomass estimates. The benefits include improved accuracy in modeling and assessing forest productivity and carbon sequestration. However, drawbacks might include the complexity of data processing, potential errors in tree matching due to positioning inaccuracies, and challenges in scaling findings from sample plots to larger regions.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand the challenges in separating ground points from vegetation points in airborne LIDAR data.
Assertion.Answer: The challenge in separating ground points from vegetation points in airborne LIDAR data arises due to the discrete return nature of the data and variations in terrain. In sloped or complex terrains, it becomes difficult to distinguish between the two types of points based solely on return order or height above ground. This difficulty is compounded by the presence of vegetation that can obscure ground points, necessitating the development of specialized algorithms, like the skewness change algorithm mentioned, to accurately separate these points for effective forest structure analysis.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the potential challenges encountered in using DGPS and total station measurements for forest structure mapping, and suggest possible solutions to improve data accuracy.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in using DGPS and total station measurements for forest structure mapping include difficulties in measuring precise coordinates due to dense canopy cover and signal obstructions. DGPS provides high accuracy but requires a clear view of the sky and calibration with reference points, while total stations measure relative coordinates needing transformation to geodetic coordinates. To improve data accuracy, integrating DGPS with additional temporary control points, using longer observation times during poor signal conditions, and employing post-processing differential correction techniques can enhance the reliability of measurements.
